titleStmt.title: A Machine-Readable Version of The True Tragedy of Richard III, 1594

publicationStmt.publisher: The true tragedie of Richard the third wherein is showne the death of Edward the fourth, with the smothering of the two yoong princes in the Tower: with a lamentable ende of Shores wife, an example for all wicked women. And lastly, the coniunction and ioyning of the two noble houses, Lancaster and Yorke. As it was playd by the Queenes Maiesties Players. , London : Printed by Thomas Creede, and are to be sold by William Barley, at his shop in Newgate Market, neare Christ Church doore, 1594.

sourceDesc.p: From the LION version of STC21009, 1594, checked against page images from EEBO

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Richard/Duke of Gloster Earl of Richmond Sir William Catesby Lord Standley older prince/King Edward V Elizabeth. ShoresWife younger prince/Yorke Lodwicke Queen King Edward IV Duke of Oxford Lord Marcus Lord Hastings Page Earl Riuers Sir Thomas Vaughan Lord Gray Oste Duke of Buckingham Sir Hapc Poetrie Truth combined voice/omnes/both/men Cardinal Messenger Ghost Hursly Sir Robert Brokenbery Master Terrill Myles Forest Will Slawter George Standley Iack Denten Captain Blunt Citizen Morton Herald. Servant Ban. Landoys Louell Perciuall Report

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enters Truth and Poetry To them the Ghost of George Duke of Clarence

l.foreign: Cresse cruor sanguinis, satietur sanguine cresse,
Quod spero scitio. O scitio, scitio, vendicta.

sp.speaker: Poetrie.
sp.l: Truth well met.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: Thanks Poetry, what makes thou upon a stage?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Shadows.

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: Then will I add bodies to the shadows,
Therefore depart and give Truth leave
to show her pageant.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: Why will Truth be a Player?

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: no, but Tragedia like for to present
A Tragedy in England done but late,
that will revive the hearts of drooping minds.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: Whereof?

sp.speaker: Truth.
sp.l: Marry thus.
Richard Plantagenet of the House of Yorke,
Claiming the Crown by wars, not by dissent,
Had as the Chronicles make manifest,
in the two and twentieth year of Henry the sixth,
by act of Parliament entailed to him
The Crown and titles to that dignity,
And to his offspring lawfully begotten,
After the decease of that forenamed King,
Yet not contented for to stay the time,
Made wars upon King Henry then the sixth,
And by outrage suppressed that virtuous King,
And won the Crown of England to himself ,
But since at Wakefield in a battle pitched,
Outrageous Richard breathed his latest breath,
Leaving behind three branches of that line,
Three sons: the first was Edward now the King,
George of Clarence and Richard Glosters Duke,
Then Henry claiming after his decease
His style, his Crown and former dignity
Was quite suppressed, till this Edward the fourth.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: But tell me truth, of Henry what ensued?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Imprisoned he, in the Tower of London lies,
by strict command, from Edward Englands King,
Since cruelly murthered, by Richard Glosters Duke.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: Whose Ghost was that did appear to us ?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: It was the ghost of George the duke of Clarece
who was attainted in King Edwards reign,
Falsely of Treason to his royalty,
Imprisoned in the Tower was most unnaturally,
by his own brother, shame to parents stock,
by Glosters Duke drowned in a but of wine.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: What shield was that he let fall?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: A shield containing this, in full effect,
Blood sprinkled, springs: blood spilt, craves due revenge:
Whereupon he writes, Cresse cruor
Quod spero scitio: O scitio scitio, vendicta.

sp.speaker: Poe.
sp.l: What manner of man was this Richard Duke of Gloster

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: A man ill shaped, crooked backed, lame armed, withal,
Valiantly minded, but tyrannous in authority,
so during the minority of the young Prince,
He is made Lord Protector over the Realm.
Gentiles suppose that Edward now hath reigned
Full two and twenty years, and now like to die,
Hath summoned all his Nobles to the Court,
to swear allegiance with the Duke his brother,
for truth unto his son the tender Prince,
Whose fathers soul is now near flight to God,
Leaving behind two sons of tender age,
Five daughters to comfort the hapless Queen,
All under the protection of the Duke of Gloster
Thus gentles, excuse the length by the matter,
And here begins Truths Pageant, Poetry
Wend with me.

body.stage: Enter Edward the fourth, Lord Hastings Lord Marcus and Elizabeth To them Richard

sp.speaker: Hastings.
sp.l: Long live my sovereign, in all happiness.

sp.speaker: Marcus.
sp.l: An honourable age with Cressus wealth,
Hourly attend the person of the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And welcome you Peers of England unto your King.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: for our unthankfulness the heavens hath thrown thee down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I fear for our ingratitude, our angry God doth frown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Nobles, he that lay me here,
Can raise me at his pleasure.
But my dear friends and kinsmen,
in what estate I now lie it is seen to you all,
And I feel myself near the dreadful stroke of death.
And the cause that I have requested you in friendly wise
to meet together is this,
that where malice and envy sowing sedition in the hearts of men
so would I have that admonished and friendly favours,
Overcome in the heart of you Lord Marcus and Lord Hastings
Both, for how I have governed these two and twenty years,
I leave it to your discretions.
The malice hath still been an enemy to you both,
that in my life time I could never get any league of amity betwixt you,
Yet at my death let me entreat you to embrace each other,
that at my last departure you may send my soul
to the joys celestial:
for leaving behind me my young son,
Your lawful King after my decease,
May be by your wise and grave counsel so governed,
which no doubt may bring comfort
to his famous realm of England.
But what saith Lord Marcus and Lord Hastings)
What not one word? nay then I see it will not be,
for they are resolute in their ambition.

sp.speaker: Elizabeth.
sp.l: Ah yield Lord Hastings,
And submit yourselves to each other:
And you Lord Marcus, submit yourself,
See here the aged King my father,
How he sues for peace betwixt you both:
Consider Lord Marcus, you are son to my mother the Queen,
And therefore let me entreat you to mitigate your wrath,
And in friendly sort, embrace each other.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay cease thy speech Elizabeth,
It is but folly to speak to them,
for they are resolute in their ambitious minds,
Therefore Elizabeth, I feel myself at the last instant of death,
And now must die being thus tormented in mind.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: May it be that thou Lord Marcus,
that neither by entreaty of the Prince,
Nor courteous word of Elizabeth his daughter,
May withdraw thy ambition from me.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: May it be that thou Lord Hastings,
Canst not perceive the mark his grace aims at.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: no I am resolute, except thou submit.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: If thou beest resolute give up the upshot,
And perhaps thy head may pay for the losses

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah Gods, since at my death you jar,
What will you do to the young Prince after my decease?
for shame I say, depart from my presence, and leave me to myself ,
for these words strikes a second dying to my soul:
Ah my Lords, I thought I could have commanded
A greater thing than this at your hands,
But since I cannot, I take my leave of you both,
And so depart and trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With shame and like your Majesty I submit therefore ,
Craving humble pardon on my knees,
And would rather that my body shall be a pray to mine enemy,
Rather than I will offend my Lord at the hour
And instance of his death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah thanks Lord Hastings.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.l: Ah yield Lord Marcus, since Lord Hastings
Is contented to be united.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah yield Lord Marcus, thou art too obstinate.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, I am content,
And humbly crave your graces pardon on my knee,
for my foul offence,
And see my Lord my breast opened to mine adversary,
that he may take revenge, then once it shall be said,
I will offend my gracious sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now let me see you friendly give one another your hands.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With a good will if it like your grace,
Therefore Lord Marcus take here my hand,
which was once vowed and sworn to be thy death,
But now through entreaty of my Prince,
I knit a league of amity forever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well Lord Hastings, not in show but in deed,
Take thou here my hand, which was once vowed
to have shivered thy body in piecemeals,
that the fowls of the air should have fed
Their young withal,
But now upon allegiance to my Prince, I vow perfect love
And five friendship forever.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now for confirming of it here take your oaths.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: If I Lord Hastings falsify my league of friendship
Vowed to Lord Marcus, I crave confusion.

sp.speaker: Marcus.
sp.l: like oath take I, and crave confusion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Confusion.
Now my Lords, for your young King, that lieth now at Ludlo
Attended with Earl Rivers, Lord Gray, his two uncles,
And the rest of the Queens kindred,
I hope you will be unto him as you have been to me,
His years are but young, thirteen at the most,
unto whose government, I commit to my brother the Protector,
But to thee Elizabeth my daughter,
I leave thee in a world of trouble,
And commend me to thy mother, to all thy sisters,
And especially I give thee this in charge upon and at my death,
Be loyal to thy brother during his authority,
As thyself art virtuous, let thy prayers be modest,
Still be bountiful in devotion.
And thus leaving thee with a kiss, I take my last farewell,
for I am so sleepy, that I must now make an end,
And here before you all, I commit my soul to almighty God,
My saviour, and sweet redeemer, my body to the earth,
My Sceptre and Crown to the young Prince my son :
And now Nobles, draw the Curtains and depart.
He that made me save me,
unto whose hands I commit my spirit.

body.stage: The King dies in his bed.
Enters Shores wife, and Hursly her maid.

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: O Fortune, wherefore wert thou called Fortune?
But that thou art fortunate?
Those whom thou favourest be famous,
Meriting mere mercy,
And fraught with mirrors of magnanimity,
And Fortune I would thou hadst never favoured me.

sp.speaker: Hurs.
sp.l: Why mistress, if you exclaim against Fortune,
You condemn yourself,
for who hath advanced you but Fortune?

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: Aye as she hath advanced me,
so may she throw me down:
But Hursly, dost not hear the King is sick?

sp.speaker: Hurs.
sp.l: Yes mistress, but never heard that every sick man died.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Ah Hursly, my mind presageth
Some great mishaps unto me,
for last time I saw the King, methought
Ghastly death approached in his face,
for thou knowest this Hursly, I have been good to all,
And still ready to prefer my friends,
to what preferment I could,
for what was it his grace would deny Shores wife?
Of any thing, yea were it half his revenues,
I know his grace would not see me want,
And if his grace should die,
As heavens forfend it should be so,
I have left me nothing now to comfort me withal,
And then those that are my foes will triumph at my fall,
But if the King scape, as I hope he will,
Then will I feather my nest,
that blow the stormy winter never so cold,
I will be thoroughly provided for one:
But here comes Lodwicke, servant to Lord Hastings,
How now Lodwicke, what news?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mistress Shore, my Lord would request you,
to come and speak with him.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: I will Lodwicke.
But tell me what news, is the King recovered?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aye mistress Shore, he hath recovered
that he long looked for.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Lodwicke, how long is it since
He began to mend?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: even when the greatest of his torments had left him.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: But are the nobles agreed to the contentment of the Prince?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The Nobles and Peers are agreed as the King would wish them.

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: Lodwicke thou revivest me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aye but few thought that the agreement and his life would have ended together.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Why Lodwicke is he dead.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: in brief mistress Shore, he hath changed his life.

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: His life, ah me unhappy woman,
Now is misery at hand,
Now will my foes triumph at this my fall,
Those whom I have done most good, will now forsake me.
Ah Hursly, when I entertained thee first,
I was far from change, so was I Lodwicke,
When I restored thee thy lands.
Ah sweet Edward, farewell my gracious Lord and sovereign,
for now shall Shores wife be a mirror and looking glass,
to all her enemies.
Thus shall I find Lodwicke, and have cause to say,
that all men are unconstant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why mistress Shore, for the loss of one friend,
will you abandon the rest that wish you well?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Ah Lodwicke I must, for when the tree decays
Whose fruitful branch have flourished many a year,
Then farewell those joyful days and offspring of my heart,
But say Lodwicke, who hath the King made Protector
During the enormity of the young Prince.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He hath made his brother Duke of Gloster Protector.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Ah me, then comes my ruin and decay,
for he could never abide me to the death,
no he always hated me whom his brother loved so well,
Thus must I lament and say, all the world is unconstant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But mistress Shore, comfort yourself,
And think well of my Lord,
who hath always been a helper unto you.

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: Indeed Lodwicke to condemn his honour I cannot,
for he hath always been my good Lord,
for as the world is fickle, so changeth the minds of men.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why mistress Shore, rather then want should oppress
You, that little land which you begged for me of the King,
Shall be at your dispose.

sp.speaker: Shorse.
sp.l: Thanks good Lodwicke.

body.stage: Enters a Citizen, and Morton a serving man.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: O master Morton, you are very welcome met,
I hope you think on me for my money.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I pray sir bear with me, and you shall have it,
With thanks too.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Nay, I pray sir let me have my money,
for I have had thanks and too much more than I looked for.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: in faith sir you shall have it,
But you must bear with me a little,
But sir, I marvel how you can be so greedy for your money,
When you see sir, we are so uncertain of our own.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: How so uncertain of mine own?
Why dost thou know any body will come to rob me?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Why no.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Wilt thou come in the night and cut my throat?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: no.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Wilt thou and the rest of thy companions,
Come and set my house on fire?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Why no, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Why how should I then be uncertain of mine own?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Why sir, by reason the King is dead.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: O sir is the King dead?
I hope he hath given you no quittance for my debt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: no sir, but I pray stay a while, and you shall have it
As soon as I can.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Well I must be content, where nothing is to be had,
The King loseth his right they say,
But who is this?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Marry sir it is mistress Shore,
to whom I am more beholding too for my service,
Then the dearest friend that ever I had.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: And I for my sons pardon.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Now mistress Shore, how fare you?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Well Morton, but not so well as thou hast known me,
for I think I shall be driven to try my friends one day.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: God forfend mistress Shore,
And happy be that Sun shall shine upon thee,
for preserving the life of my son.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Gramercies good father,
But how doth thy son, is he well?

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: The better that thou lives, doth he.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Thanks father, I am glad of it,
But come master Lodwicke shall we go?
And you Morton, you will bear us company.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aye mistress Shore,
for my Lord thinks long for our coming.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: There there, huffer, but by your leave,
The Kings death is a maim to her credit,
But they say, there is my Lord Hastings in the Court,
He is as good as the Ace of hearts at maw,
Well even as they brew, so let them bake for me:
But I must about the streets, to see if I can meet
With such cold customers as they I met withal even now,
Mass if I meet with no better,
I am like to keep a bad household of it.

body.stage: Enters Richard sir William Casbe Page of his chamber, and his train.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: My friends depart,
The hour commands your absence.
Leave me, and every man look to his charge.

sp.speaker: Casbie.
sp.l: Renowned and right worthy Protector,
Whose excellency far deserves the name of king than protector,
Sir William Casbie wisheth my Lord,
that your grace may so govern the young Prince,
that the Crown of England may flourish in all happiness.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Ah young Prince, and why not I?
Or who shall inherit Plantagines but his son ?
And who the King deceased, but the brother?
Shall law bridle nature, or authority hinder inheritance?
no, I say no: Principality brooks no equality,
Much less superiority,
And the title of a King, is next under the degree of a God,
for if he be worthy to be called valiant,
that in his life wins honour, and by his sword wins riches,
Why now I with renown of a soldier, which is never sold but
by weight, nor changed but by loss of life,
I reaped not the gain but the glory, and since it becommeth
A son to maintain the honour of his deceased father,
Why should not I hazard his dignity by my brothers sons?
to be baser than a King I disdain,
And to be more than Protector, the law deny,
Why my father got the Crown, my brother won the Crown,
And I will wear the Crown,
Or I will make them hop without their crowns that denies me:
have I removed such logs out of my sight, as my brother Clarence
And king Henry the sixth, to suffer a child to shadow me,
Nay more, my nephew to disinherit me,
Yet most of all, to be released from the yoke of my brother
As I term it, to become subject to his son ,
no death nor hell shall not withhold me, but as I rule I will reign,
And so reign that the proudest enemy shall not abide
The sharpest shower. Why what are the babes but a puff of
Gun powder? a mark for the soldiers, food for fishes,
Or lining for beds, devices enough to make them away,
Wherein I am resolute, and determining, needs no counsel,
Ho, whose within?

sp.speaker: Perc.
sp.l: May it please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: ha villain, Majesty.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I speak but upon that which shall be my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: But what is he with thee?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: A Messenger with a letter from the right honourable
The Duke of Buckingham

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sirrah give place.
Ah how this title of Majesty, animates me to my purpose,
Rise man, regard no fall, happily this letter brings good luck,
May it be, or is it possible,
Doth Fortune so much favour my happiness
that I no sooner devise, but she sets abroach?
Or doth she but to try me, that raising me aloft,
My fall may be the greater, well laugh on sweet change,
Be as be may, I will never fear colours nor regard ruth,
Valour brings fame, and fame conquers death.
Perciuall.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: for so thy letter declares thy name,
Thy trust to thy Lord, is a sufficient warrant
that I utter my mind fully unto thee,
And seeing thy Lord and I have been long foes,
And have found now so fit opportunity to join league,
to allay the proud enemy, tell him thus as a friend,
I do accept of his grace, and will be as ready to put in practise
to the uttermost of my power, what ere he shall be to devise,
But whereas he hath writ that the removing of the young
Prince from the Queens friends might do well,
Tell him thus, it is the only way to our purpose,
for he shall shortly come up to London to his Coronation,
At which instant, we will be both present,
And where by the help of thy Lord I will so play my part,
that I will be more than I am, and not much less than I look for
no nor a hair breadth from that I am,
A judge thou what it is Perciual

sp.speaker: Perc.
sp.l: God send it my Lord, but my Lord willed me to satisfy you, and to tell you by word of mouth that he hath in readiness a brave company of men.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What power hath he?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A brave band of his own.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What number?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Lord, to the number of five hundredth footmen. And horsemen aiders unto him, is my Lord Chamberlain, and my Lord Hastings.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: 'Swounds, dares he trust the Lord Hastings.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Aye my Lord as his own life, he is secret I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well Perciuall, this matter is weighty and must not be slipped, therefore return this answer to thy Lord, that tomorrow I will meet him, for today I cannot, for now the funeral is past I must set a screen before the fire for fear of suspicion: again, I am now to strengthen myself by the controversy that is betwixt the kindred of the King deceased, and the Queen that is living, the young Prince is yet in hucksters handling, and they not thoroughly friends, now must I so work, that that water that drives the mill may drown it. I climb Perciuall, I regard more the glory than the gain, for the very name of a King redouble a man's life with fame, when death hath done his worst, and so commend me to thy Lord, and take thou this for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I thank your grace, I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Why so, now Fortune make me a King, Fortune give me a kingdom, let the world report the Duke of Gloster was a King, therefore Fortune make me King, if I be but King for a year, nay but half a year, nay a month, a week, three days, one day, or half a day, nay an hour, 'swounds half an hour, nay sweet Fortune, clap but the Crown on my head, that the vassals may but once say, God save King Richards life, it is enough. Sirrah, who is there?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What hearest thou about the Court?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Joy my Lord of your Protectorship for the most part,
Some murmur, but my Lord they be of the baser sort.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: A mighty arm will sway the baser sort, authority doth terrify.
But what other news hearest thou?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: This my Lord, they say the young king is coming up to his coronation, attended on by his two uncles, Earl Rivers and Lord Gray, and the rest of the Queens kindred.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A parlous bone to ground upon, and a rush stiffly knit, which if I could find a knot, I would give one half to the dogs and set fire on the other.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: It is reported my Lord, but I know not whether it be true or no, that the Duke of Buckingham is up in the Marches of Wales with a band of men, and as they say, he aims at the Crown.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Tush a shadow without a substance, and a fear without a cause: but yet if my neighbours house be on fire, let me seek to save mine own, in trust is treason, time slippeth, it is ill jesting with edge tools, or dallying with Princes matters, I will strike whilst the iron is hot, and I will trust never a Duke of Buckingham, no never a Duke in the world, further than I see him. And sirrah, so follow me.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I see my Lord is fully resolved to climb, but how he climbs I will leave that to your judgments, but what his fall will be that is hard to say: But I marvel that the Duke of Buckingham and he are now become such great friends, who had wont to love one another so well as the spider doth the fly: but this I have noted, since he hath had the charge of Protector, how many noble men hath fled the realm, first the Lord Marcus son to the Queen, the Earl of Westmorland and Northumberland are secretly fled: how this gear will cotton I know not. But what do I meddling in such matters, that should meddle with the untying of my Lords points, faith do even as a great many do beside, meddle with Princes matters so long, till they prove themselves beggars in the end. therefore I for fear I should be taken nipping with any words, I will set a lock on my lips, for fear my tongue grow too wide for my mouth.

body.stage: Enter the young Prince his brother, Duke of Yorke Earl Rivers Lord Gray sir Hapce sir Thomas Vaughan

sp.speaker: Kng.
sp.p: Right loving uncles, and the rest of this company, my mother hath written, and thinks it convenient that we dismiss our train, for fear the town of Northampton is not able to receive us: and again my uncle of Gloster may rather think we come of malice against him and his blood: therefore my Lords, let me hear your opinions, for my words and her letters are all one: and besides I myself give consent.

sp.speaker: Riuers.
sp.p: Then thus may it please your grace, I will show my opinion. First note the two houses of Lancaster and Yorke the league of friendship is yet but green betwixt them, and little cause of variance may cause it break, and thereby I think it not requisite to discharge the company because of this. The Duke of Buckingham is up in the Marches of Wales with a great power, and with him is joined the Protector, for what cause I know not, therefore my Lords, I have spoken my mind boldly, but do as your honours shall think good.

sp.speaker: Vaugh.
sp.l: Why my Lord Rivers, wherefore is he Protector but for the Kings safety?

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: Aye sir Thomas Vaughan, and therefore a traitor, because he is Protector.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: we have the Prince in charge, therefore we need not care.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: we have the Prince, but they the authority.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Why take you not the Duke of Buckingham for the Kings friend?

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: Yes, and yet we may misdoubt the Duke of Gloster as a foe.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Why then my Lord Rivers, I think it is convenient that we leave you here behind us at Northamton for conference with them, and if you hear their pretence be good towards the King, you may in Gods name make return and come with them, but if not, leave them and come to us with speed. for my sister the Queen hath willed that we should dismiss our company, and the King himself hath agreed to it, therefore we must needs obey.

sp.speaker: Riuers.
sp.l: If it please your grace I am content, and humbly take my leave of you all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Farewell good uncle, ah gods, if I do live my fathers years as God forbid but I may, I will so root out this malice and envy sown among the nobility, that I will make them weary that were the first beginners of these mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Worthily well spoken of your princely Majesty,
which no doubt showeth a king like resolution.

sp.speaker: Vaughon.
sp.l: A toward young Prince, and no doubt forward to all virtue, whose reign God long prosper among us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But come uncle, let us forward of our journey towards London.

sp.speaker: Riuers.
sp.l: we will attend upon your Majesty.

body.stage: Enters an old Inn keeper, and Richards Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Come on mine Host, what dost thou understand my tale or no?

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.p: I faith my guest you have amazed me already, and to hear it again, it will mad me altogether, but because I may think upon it the better, I pray you let me hear it once more.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why then thus, I serve the right honourable the Lord Protector.

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.l: I, know that too well.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Then this is his graces pleasure, that this night he will be lodged in thy house, thy fare must be sumptuous, thy lodgings cleanly, his men used friendly and with great courtesy, and that he may have his lodging prepared as near Lord Rivers as possible may be

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.l: Why sir if this be all, this is done already.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Nay more.

sp.speaker: Ost.
sp.p: Nay sir, and you love me no more, here is too much already.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay, my Lords graces pleasure is further, that when all thy guess have taken their chambers, that thou convey into my Lords hands the keys of every several chamber, and what my Lords pleasure is further, thou shalt know in the morning.

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.p: How lock in my guess like prisoners, why do you hear my guess? methinks there should be little better than treason in these words you have uttered.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Treason villain, how darest thou have a thought of treason against my Lord, therefore you were best be brief, and tell me whether you will do it or no?

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.p: Alas what shall I do? who were I best to offend? shall I betray that good old Earl that hath lain at my house this forty years? why if I do he will hang me: nay then on the other side, if I should not do as my Lord Protector commands, he will chop off my head, but is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Come sir be brief, there is no remedy, therefore be brief and tell me straight.

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.p: Why then sir here is my hand, tell my Lord Protector he shall have it, I will do as he commands me, but even against my will, God is my witness.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why then farewell mine Host.

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.p: Farewell even the worst guest that ever came to my house, A masters, masters, what a troublesome vocation am I crept into, you think we that be inn keepers get all the world, but I think I shall get a fair halter to my neck, but I must go see all things done to my great grief.

body.stage: Enters the mother Queen,and her daughter, and her son, to sanctuary.
Earl Rivers speaks out of his chamber.

sp.speaker: Oste.
sp.l: Ho mine Host, Chamberlain where is my key?
What penned up like a prisoner? But stay, I fear I am betrayed,
The sudden sight of Glosters Duke, doth make me sore afraid:
I will speak to him, and gently him salute,
though in my heart I envy much the man,
God morrow my Lord Protector to your grace,
And Duke of Buckingham God morrow too,
Thanks noble Dukes for our good cheer, and for your company.

body.stage: Here enters Buckingham and Gloster and their train.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Thou wretched Earl, whose aged head imagines nought but treachery,
like Judas thou admitted wast to sup with us last night,
But heavens prevented thee our ills, and left thee in this plight:
Grievest thou that I the Gloster Duke, should as Protector sway?
And were you he was left behind, to make us both away?
Wilt thou be ringleader to wrong, and must you guide the realm?
Nay over board all such mates I hurl, whilst I do guide the helm:
I will weed you out by one and one, I will burn you up like chaff,
I will rend your stock up by the roots, that yet in triumphs laugh.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: Alas good Dukes for aught I know, I never did offend,
Except unto my Prince unloyal I have been,
Then show just cause, why you exclaim so rashly in this sort,
so falsely thus me to condemn, upon some false report:
But am I here as prisoner kept, imprisoned here by you?
Then know, I am as true to my Prince, as the proudest in thy crew.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: A bravely spoken good old Earl, who though his limbs be numb,
He hath his tongue as much at use, as though his years were young.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Speakest you the truth, how darest you speak, for justice to appeal?
When as thy packing with thy Prince, thy falsehood do reveal.
A Rivers blush, for shame to speak, like traitor as thou art.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: A brayed you me as traitor to your grace:
no although a prisoner, I return defiance in thy face.
The Chronicles I record, talk of my fidelity, and of my progeny,
where, as in a glass you mayst behold, thy ancestors and their treachery.
The wars in France Irish conflicts, and Scotland knows my trust,
When thou hast kept thy skin unscarred, and let thine armour rust.
How thou unjustly here exclaimest,
Yea far from love or kin,
Was this the oath which at our princes death,
With us thou didst combine?
But time permits now, to tell thee all my mind:
for well it is known that but for fear, you never would have clined.
Let Commons now have it in hand, the matter is begun,
Of whom I fear the lesser sort, upon thy part will run.
My Lords, I cannot breath it out in words like to you: but this,
My honour I will set to sale, let any common man come in,
And say Earl Rivers faith unto his Prince did quail,
Then will I lose my lands and life, but if none so can do,
Then thou Protector injurest me, and thy copartner too:
But since as Judges here you are, and taking no remorse,
Spare me not, let me have law, in justice do your worst.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: My Lord, lay down a cooling card, this game is gone too far,
You have him fast, now cut him off, for fear of civil war.
Injurious Earl, I hardly brooke, this portion thou hast given,
Thus with my honour me to touch, but thy ruth shall begin.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: But as thou art I leave thee here,
unto the officers custody,
First bare him to Pomphret Castle,
Charge them to keep him secretly:
And as you hear from me so deal,
Let it be done immediately:
Take from our Garrison one whole band,
to guard him thither safely.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: And sendst thou me to common Jail?
Nay then I know thy mind:
God bless these young and tender babes,
that I do leave behind.
And God above protect them day and night,
Those are the marks thou aimest at, to rid them from their right.
Farewell sweet England and my country men,
Earl Rivers leads the way:
Yet would my life might rid you from this thrall,
But for my stock and kindred to the Queen, I greatly fear the all
And thus disloyal Duke farewell, when ever this is known,
The shame and infamy thereof, be sure will be thine own .

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: so now my Lord of Buckingham, let us hoist up sail while the wind serves, this hot beginning must have a quick dispatch, therefore I charge and command straightly, that every high way be laid close, that none may be suffered to carry this news before we ourselves come, for if word come before us, then is our pretence bewrayed, and all we have done to no effect. If any ask the cause why they may not pass, use my authority, and if he resist shoot him through. Now my Lord of Buckingham, let us take post horse to Stony Stratford, where happily I will say such grace to the Princes dinner, that I will make the devoutest of them forget what meat they eat, and yet all for the best I hope

body.stage: Enter the young Prince Lord Gray sir Thomas Vaughon sir Richard Hapc and their train.

sp.speaker: Hapc.
sp.l: Lord Gray, you do discomfort the King by reason of your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: Alas sir Richard, how can I be merry when we have so great a charge of his grace: and again this makes me to grieve the more, because we cannot hear from Earl Rivers, which makes me think the Protector and he have been at some words.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why good uncle comfort yourself, no doubt my uncle Earl Rivers is well, and is coming no doubt with my uncle of Gloster to meet us, else we should have heard to the contrary. If any have cause to fear, it is myself, therefore good uncle comfort yourself and be not sad.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: The sweet juice of such a grape would comfort a man were he half dead, and the sweet words of such a Prince would make men careless of mishaps, how dangerous soever.

sp.speaker: Hap.
sp.p: Lord Gray, we hear now by all likelihoods the Protector not to be far, therefore we are to entertain him and the Duke of Buckingham with courtesy, both for the Princes behalf and for our own.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Sir Richard Hapc, I shall hardly show the Protector or the Duke of Buckingham any merry countenance, considering how hardly I have been used by them both, but yet for love to my prince I will bridle my affection, but in good time they come.

body.stage: Enters Richard Duke of Buckingham and their train.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Long live my Princely Nephew in all happiness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thanks uncle of Gloster for your courtesy, yet you have made haste, for we looked not for you as yet.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Therein I show my humble duty to your grace, whose life I wish to redouble your deceased fathers days.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks good uncle.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Long live my gracious Prince.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks Buckingham, but uncle you will bear us company towards London?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: for that cause we came.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Gentlemen on afore keep your rooms, how now Lord Gray, do you jostle in the presence of the King? This is more than needs.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.l: My Lord, I scarce touched you, I hope it be no offence.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Sir no great offence, but inward envy will burst out, no Lord Gray, you cannot hide your malice to us of the Kings blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why good uncle let me know the cause of your sudden quarrel?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Marry thus noble Nephew, the old wound of envy, being rubbed by Lord Grayes venomous rashness, is grown to such a venomous sore that it is incurable, without remove of dead flesh.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Lord Gray, I do so much dislike thy abuse, that were it not in presence of the Prince, I would bid thee combat: but thus and it shall like your grace, I arrest, and attach this Lord Gray, Sir Thomas Vaughon, and Richard Hapce, of high treason to your grace. And that Lord Gray hath conveyed money out of the Tower to relieve our enemies the Scots, and now by currying favour with your Majesty, he thinks it to be hid.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Only this I add, you govern the Prince without my authority, allowing me no more than the bare name of Protector, which I will have in the despite of you, and therefore as your competitor Earl Rivers is already imprisoned, so shall you be, till time afford the law to take place.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: But whereas we are attached as traitors to his grace, and govern him without your authority, why we have authority from the mother Queen. And for the delivery of the money to the Scots, it was done by a general consent of you all, and that I have your hands to show for my discharge, therefore your arrest and attachment is not lawful: and yet as lawful as your quarrel is right.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Thy presumption condemns thee Lord Gray, thy arrest is lawful. Therefore see them speedily and secretly imprisoned, and after the coronation they shall answer it by law, mean while, Officers look to your charge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A Gods, and is it justice without my consent? Am I a King and bear no authority? My loving kindred committed to prison as traitors in my presence, and I stand to give aim at them. A Edward, would thou layest by thy fathers side, or else he had lived till thou hadst been better able to rule. If my near kindred be committed to prison, what remains for me, a crown? A but how? so beset with sorrows, that the care and grief will kill me ere I shall enjoy my kingdom. Well since I cannot command, I will entreat Good uncle of Gloster, for all I can say little, but for my uncle Lord Gray, what need he be a thief or convey money out of the Tower, when he hath sufficient of his own? But good uncle let me bail them all: If not, I will bail my uncle Lord Gray if I may.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Your grace undertakes you know not what, the matters are perilous, especially against the Lord Gray.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What perilous matters, considering he is a friend to us ?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: He may be a friend to win favour, and so climb to promotion in respect of his equals. His equals, nay his betters.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know my uncle will conceal no treason, or dangerous secrecy from us.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Yes secrets that are too subtle for babes, Alas my Lord you are a child, and they use you as a child: but they consult and conclude of such matters, as were we not careful, would prove prejudicial to your Majesties person. Therefore let not your grace fear any thing by our determination, for as my authority is only under your grace, so shall my loyalty deserve hereafter the just recompense of a true subject, therefore I having charge from my brother your father, and our late deceased king, during the minority of your grace, I will use my authority as I see good.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye me unhappy king.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Nay let not your grace be dismayed for our imprisonment, but I would we could warrant your grace from harm, and so we humbly take our leaves of your grace, hoping that ere long we shall answer by law to the shame and disgrace of you all.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Go, you shall answer it by law.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: But come uncle shall we to Lon to our untimely coronation?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: What else and please your majesty, where by the way I will appoint trusty Officers about you.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Sound Trumpet in this parley, God save the King.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Richard.

body.stage: Enter the mother Queen, and her young son the Duke of Yorke and Elizabeth

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: May it please your grace to show to your children the cause of your heaviness, that we knowing it, may be copartners of your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Aye me poor husbandless queen, and you poor fatherless princes.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Good mother expect the living, and forget the dead. What though our father be dead, yet behold his children, the image of himself.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Aye poor Princes, my mourning is for you and for your brother, who is gone up to an untimely coronation.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.p: Why mother he is a Prince, and in hands of our two uncles, Earl Rivers, and Lord Gray, who will no doubt be careful of his estate.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I know they will, but kings have mortal enemies, as well as friends that esteem and regard them. A sweet children, when I am at rest my nightly dreams are dreadful. Methinks as I lie in my bed, I see the league broken which was sworn at the death of your kingly father, it is this my children and many other causes of like importance, that makes your aged mother to lament as she doth.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: May it please your grace.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: A my son, no more grace, for I am so sore disgraced, that without Gods grace, I fall into despair with myself, but who is this?

sp.speaker: York.
sp.p: What art thou that with thy ghastly looks presseth into sanctuary, to affright our mother Queen.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: A sweet Princes, doth my countenance bewray me? My news is doubtful and heavy.

sp.speaker: Eliz.
sp.l: Then utter it to us, that our mother may not hear it.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: A yes my friend, speak what ere it be.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Then thus may it please your grace, The young prince coming up to his coronation, attended on by his two uncles, Earl Rivers, and Lord Gray, and the rest of your kindred, was by the Duke of Buckingham and the Protector, met at stony Stratford where on a sudden grew malice between the Duke of Buckingham and the Lord Gray, but in the end, the Duke of Buckinghams malice grew so great, that he arrested and attached all those of your kindred of high treason, whereupon the Protector being too rash in judgment, hath committed them all to Pomphret Castle.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Where I fear he will butcher them all, but where is the Prince my son?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: He remains at London in the Bishops palace, in the hands of the Protector.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: A traitors, will they lay hands on their Prince, and imprison his Peers, which no doubt means well towards him: But tell me, art not thou servant to the Arch Bishop of Yorke

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: Yes if it please your grace, for himself is here at hand with Letters from the Council, and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: But here my friend, grief had almost made me forget thy reward. A come my Lord, thou bringest the heavy news, come shoot thine arrow, and hit this heart that is almost dead with grief already.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What ere my news be, have patience, the Duke of Gloster greets your grace.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Draw home my Lord, for now you hit the mark.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Prince your son doth greet your grace.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: A happy gale that blew that arrow by, A let me see the Letter that he sent, perhaps it may prolong my life a while.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: How doth my brother, is he in health my Lord?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: in health sweet Prince, but longs to have thy company.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I am content, if my mother will let me go.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Content or not, sweet Prince it must be so.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Hold, and have they persuaded thee my son to have thy brother too away from me, nay first I will know what shall become of thee, before I send my other son to them.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: look on this Letter and advise yourself , for thus the Council hath determined.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: And have they chosen thee among the rest, for to persuade me to this enterprise? no my Lord, and thus persuade yourself, I will not send him to be butchered.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Your grace misdoubts the worst, they send for him only to have him bedfellow to the King, and there to stay and keep him company. And if your son miscarry, then let his blood be laid unto my charge: I know their drifts and what they do pretend, for they shall both this night sleep in the Tower, and tomorrow they shall come forth to his happy coronation. upon my honour this is the full effect, for see the ambushed nobles are at hand to take the Prince away from you by force, if you will not by fair means let him go.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Why my Lord will you break Sanctuary, and bring in rebels to affright us thus? no, you shall rather take away my life before you get my boy away from me.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Why Madam have you taken Sanctuary?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, and high time too I trow.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: A heavy case when Princes fly for aide, where cut throats, rebels, and bankrupts should be. But Madam what answer do you return, if I could persuade you, it were best to let him go.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: But for I see you counsel for the best, I am content that you shall have my son, in hope that you will send him safe to me, here I deliver him into your hands. Farewell my boy, commend me to thy brother.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: Mother farewell, and farewell sister too, I will but see my brother and return to you.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Tears stops my speech. Come let us in my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will attend upon your grace. Hold take the Prince, the Queen and I have done, I will take my leave, and after you I will come.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: How now my friend, shall I go to my brother?

sp.speaker: Cates.
sp.l: What else sweet Prince, and for that cause we are come, to bear you company.

body.stage: Enter four watch men. Enter Richards Page.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Why thus by keeping company, am I become like unto those with whom I keep company. As my Lord hopes to wear the Crown, so I hope by that means to have preferment, but in steed of the Crown, the blood of the headless light upon his head: he hath made but a wrong match, for blood is a threatener and will have revenge. He makes havoc of all to bring his purpose to pass: all those of the Queens kindred that were committed to Pomphret Castle, he hath caused them to be secretly put to death without judgment: the like was never seen in England. He spares none whom he but mistrusteth to be a hinderer to his proceedings, he is straight chopped up in prison The valiant Earl of Oxford being but mistrusted, is kept close prisoner in Hames Castle. again, how well Doctor Shaw hath pleased my Lord, that preached at Paules Cross yesterday, that proved the two Princes to be bastards, whereupon in the after noon came down my Lord Mayor and the Aldermen to Baynards Castle, and offered my Lord the whole estate upon him, and offered to make him King, which he refused so faintly, that if it had been offered once more, I know he would have taken it, the Duke of Buckingham is gone about it, and is now in the Guild Hall making his Oration. But here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Catesby content thee, I have warned the Lord Hastings to this Court, and since he is so hard to be won, it is better to cut him off than suffer him, he hath been all this while partaker to our secrets, and if he should but by some mislike utter it, then were we all cast away.

sp.speaker: Cates.
sp.p: Nay my Lord do as you will, yet I have spoken what I can in my friends cause.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Go to no more ado Catesby, they say I have been a long sleeper today , but I will be awake anon to some of their costs. But sirrah are those men in readiness that I appointed you to get?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Aye my Lord, and give diligent attendance upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Go to, look to it then Catesby, get thee thy weapons ready, for I will enter the Court.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Doth my Lord say he hath been a long sleeper today ? There are those of the Court that are of another opinion, that thinks his grace lieth never long enough a bed. Now there is court held today by diverse of the Council, which I fear me will cost the Lord Hastings and the Lord Standley their best caps: for my Lord hath willed me to get half a dozen ruffians in readiness, and when he knocks with his fist upon the board, they to rush in, and to cry, treason, treason, and to lay hands upon the Lord Hastings, and the Lord Stannley, which for fear I should let slip, I will give my diligent attendance.

body.stage: Enter Richard, Catesby and others, pulling Lord Hastings

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Come bring him away, let this suffice, thou and that accursed sorceress the mother Queen hath bewitched me, with assistance of that famous strumpet of my brothers, Shores wife: my withered arm is a sufficient testimony, deny it if thou canst: lay not Shores wife with thee last night?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: that she was in my house my Lord I cannot deny, but not for any such matter. If.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: If villain, seedest thou me with Ifs and ands, go fetch me a Priest, make a short shrift, and dispatch him quickly for by the blessed Saint Paule I swear, I will not dine till I see the traitors head, away sir Thomas, suffer him not to speak, see him executed straight, and let his copartner the Lord Standly be carried to prison also, it is not his broke head I have gives him, shall excuse him.

Catesbie go you and see it presently proclaimed throughout the City of London by a Herald of Arms, that the cause of his death and the rest, were for conspiring by Witchcraft the death of me and the Duke of Buckingham, that so they might govern, the King and rule the realm, I think the proclamation be almost done.

sp.speaker: Cate.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord, and finished too.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well then about it. But hearest thou Catesbie, mean while I will listen after success of the Duke of Buckingham, who is labouring all this while with the Citizens of London to make me King, which I hope shall be shortly, for thou seest our foes now are fewer, and we nearer the mark than before, and when I have it, look thou for the place of thy friend the Lord Hastings, mean while about thy business.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Now sirrah to thee, there is one thing more undone, which grieves me more than all the rest: and to say the truth, it is of more importance than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Ah that my Lord would utter it to his Page, then should I count myself a happy man, if I could ease my Lord of that great doubt.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I commend thy willingness, but it is too mighty and reacheth the stars.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: The more weighty it is, the sooner shall I by doing it, increase your honours good liking toward me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Be assured of that, but the matter is of weight and great importance, and doth concern the state.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Why my Lord, I will choke them with gifts that shall perform it, therefore good my Lord, trust me in this cause.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Indeed thy trust I know to be so true, that I care not to utter it unto thee. Come hither, and yet the matter is too weighty for so mean a man.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Yet good my Lord, utter it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Why thus it is, I would have my two Nephews the young Prince and his brother secretly murthered, 'Swounds villain it is out, wilt thou do it? or wilt thou betray me?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Lord you shall see my forwardness herein, I am acquainted with one Iames Terrell, that lodgeth hard by your honours chamber, with him my Lord will I so work, that soon at night you shall speak with him.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Of what reputation or calling is that Terrell, may we trust him with that which once known, were the utter confusion of me and my friends forever?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: for his trust my Lord, I dare be bound, only this, a poor gentleman he is, hoping for preferment by your grace, and upon my credit my Lord, he will see it done.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well in this be very circumspect and sure with thy diligence, be liberal, and look for a day to make thee bless thyself , wherein thou servedest so good a Lord. And now that Shores wife's goods be confiscate, go from me to the Bishop of London, and see that she receive her open penance, let her be turned out of prison, but so bare as a wretch that worthily hath deserved that plague: and let there be straight proclamation made by my Lord the Mayor, that none shall relieve her nor pity her, and privy spies set in every corner of the City, that they may take notice of them that relieves her: for as her beginning was most famous above all, so will I have her end most infamous above all. have care now my boy, and win thy masters heart forever .

sp.speaker: Shores.
sp.p: Ah unfortunate Shores wife, dishonour to the King, a shame to thy country, and the only blot of defame to all thy kindred: Aye why was I made fair that a King should favour me? But my friends should have preferred discipline before affection: for they know of my folly, yea my own husband knew of my breach of disloyalty, and yet suffered me, by reason he knew it bootless to kick against the prick. A sweet King Edward, little didst thou think Shores wife should have been so hardly used, thy unnatural brother not consent with my goods which are yet confiscate in his custody, but yet more to add to my present misery, hath proclaimed upon great penalty, that none whatsoever, shall either aide or succour me, but here being comfortless to die in the streets with hunger. I am constrained to beg, but I fear it is in vain, for none will pity me. Yet here come one to whom I have done good, in restoring his lands that were lost, now will I try him to see if he will give me anything.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Ah time how thou sufferest fortune to alter estates, and changest the minds of the good for the worst. How many headless Peers sleep in their graves, whose places are furnish with their inferiors? Such as are neither nobly borne, nor virtuously minded. My heart hardly bewails the loss of the young King, by the outrage of the Protector, who hath proclaimed himself King, by the name of Richard the third. The Commons murmur at it greatly, that the young King and his brother should be imprisoned, but to what end it is hard to say, but many think they shall never come forth again. But God do all for the best and that the right heirs may not be utterly overthrown.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Ah gods what a grief is it for me to ask, where I have given.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ah my good Lord Hastings, how innocently thou didst the heavens bear witness.

sp.speaker: Shores wife.
sp.l: Good sir take pity upon me, and relieve me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Indeed it is pity to see so fair a face to ask for alms; But tell me, hast thou no friends?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Yes sir I had many friends, but when my chiefest friend of all died, the rest then forsook me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Belike then thy fact was notorious, that thy friends leaving thee would let thee go as a spoil for villains. But hearst thou, I prithee tell me the truth, and as I am a gentleman, I will pity thee?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Ah Lodowick, tell thee the truth, why half this entreaty served thee, when thy lands had been clean gone had it not been for Shores wife, and dost thou make me so long to beg for a little.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Indeed my lands I had restored me by mistress Shore, but may this be she?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Aye Lodowicke, I am she that begged thy lands of King Edward the fourth, therefore I pray thee bestow something on me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Ah gods what is this world, and how uncertain are riches? Is this she that was in such credit with the King? Nay more, that could command a King indeed? I cannot deny but my lands she restored me, but shall I by relieving of her hurt myself, no: for straight proclamation is made that none shall succour her, therefore for fear I should be seen talk with her, I will shun her company and get me to my chamber, and there set down in heroical verse, the shameful end of a Kings Concubine, which is no doubt as wonderful as the desolation of a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Shores.
sp.p: Ah Lodowick if thou wilt give me nothing, yet stay and talk with me. Ah no he shuns my company, all my friends now forsake me: in prosperity I had many, but in adversity none. Ah gods have I this for my good I have done, for when I was in my chiefest pomp, I thought that day well spent wherein I might pleasure my friend by suits to the King, for if I had spoken, he would not have said nay. for though he was King, yet Shores wife swayed the sword. Aye where need was, there was I bountiful, and mindful I was still upon the poor to relieve them, and now none will know me nor succour me: therefore here shall I die for want of sustenance. Yet here comes another whom I have done good unto in saving the life of his son, well I will try him, to see if he will give me any thing.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: no men no laws, no Princes no orders, all is hushed neighbour now he is king, but before he was king how was the tems thwacked with ruffians? what frays had we in the streets? Now he hath proclaimed peace between Scotland and England for six years, to what end I know not, usurpers had need to be wise.

sp.speaker: Shores.
sp.l: Ah good sir relieve me, and bestow something upon me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ah neighbour, hedges have eyes, and high ways have ears but who is it a beggar woman? the streets are full of them, in faith. But here is thou, hast thou no friends that thou goest a begging so?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Yes sir I had friends, but they are all dead as you are.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.l: Why am I dead neighbour? why thou arrant quean what meanest thou by that?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: I mean they are dead in charity. But I pray sir, had not you the life of your son saved in the time of king Edward the fourth, by one Shores wife?

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.p: Yes marry had I, but art thou a sprig of the same bough? I promise you neighbour I thought so, that so idle a housewife could not be without the acquaintance of so noble a strumpet: well for her sake I will give thee somewhat.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Nay then know, that I am she that saved the life of thy condemned son.

sp.speaker: Citi.
sp.p: who art thou Shores wife? Lie still purse, neighbour I would not for twenty pounds have given her one farthing, the proclamation is so hard by king Richard. Why minion are you she that was the dishonour to the King? the shame to her husband, the discredit to the City? hear you, lay your fingers to work, and get thereby somewhat to maintain you. O neighbour I grow very choleric, and thou didst save the life of my son, why if thou hadst not, another would : and for my part, I would he had been hanged seven years ago, it had saved me a great deal of money then. But come let us go in, and let the quean alone.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Alas thus am I become an open shame to the world, here shall I die in the streets for want of sustenance, alas is my fact so heinous that none will pity me? Yet here comes another to whom I have done good, who is least able to pleasure me, yet I will try him, to see if he will give me any thing.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Now sir, who but king Richard bears sway, and hath proclaimed Iohn Earl of Linclone heir apparent to the Crown, the young Princes they are in the Tower, nay some says more, they are murthered. But this makes me to muse, the Duke of Buckingham and the King is at such variance, that did all in all to help him to the Crown, but the Duke of Buckingham is rid down to Breaknock Castle in Wales and there he means to raise up a power to pull down the usurper: but let them agree as they will, for the next fair wind I will over seas.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Ah Shores wife, so near driven, to beg of a serving-man, Aye , necessity hath no law, I must needs. Good sir relieve me, and give me something.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Why what art thou?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: in brief Morton, I am Shores wife, that have done good to all.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: Ah fool, and ever thy own enemy. in troth mistress Shore, my store is but small, yet as it is, we will part stakes, but soft I cannot do what I would, I am watched.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Good Morton relieve me.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: What should I relieve my Kings enemy?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Why thou promised thou wouldst.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: I tell thee I will not, and so be answered. 'Swounds I would with all my heart, but for yonder villain, a plague on him.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: An honest fellow I warrant him. How now Shores wife, will none relieve thee?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: no none will relieve her, that hath been good to all.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why it were pity to do thee good, but methinks she is fulsome and stinks.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: If I be fulsome shun my company, for none but thy Lord sought my misery, and he hath undone me.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Why hath he undone thee? nay thy wicked and naughty life hath undone thee, but if thou wantest maintenance, why dost thou not fall to thy old trade again?

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Nay villain, I have done open penance, and am sorry for my sins that are past.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: 'Swounds is Shores wife become an holy whore, nay then we shall never have done.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: Why hang thee, if thy faults were so written in thy forehead as mine is, it would be as wrong with thee. But I prithee leave me, and get thee from me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And cannot you keep the City but you must run gadding to the Court, and you stay here a little longer, I will make you be set away, and for my part, would all whores were so served, then there would be fewer in England then there be. And so farewell good mistress Shore.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.p: And all such usurping kings as thy Lord is, may come to a shameful end, which no doubt I may live yet to see. therefore sweet God forgive all my foul offence:
sp.l: And though I have done wickedly in this world,
Into hell fire, let not my soul be hurled.

body.stage: Enter Master Terrill and sir Robert Brokenbery

sp.speaker: Broken.
sp.p: Master Terrell, the King hath written, that for one night I should deliver you the keys, and put you in full possession But good Master. Terrell, may I be so bold to demand a question without offence?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Else God forbid, say on what ere it be.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Then this master Terrell, for your coming I partly know the cause, for the king oftentimes hath sent to me to have them both dispatched, but because I was a servant to their father being Edward the fourth, my heart would never give me to do the deed.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Why sir Robert you are beside the matter, what need
you use such speeches what matters are between the King and me, I pray you leave it, and deliver me the keys.

sp.speaker: Broken.
sp.l: Ah here with tears I deliver you the keys, and so farewell master Terrell.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Alas good sir Robert, he is kind hearted, but it must not prevail, what I have promised the King I must perform. But ho Myles Forest.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Myles Forest, have you got those men I spake of, they must be resolute and pitiless.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I warrant you sir, they are such pitiless villains, that all London cannot match them for their villainy, one of their names is Will Sluter, yet the most part calls him black Will, the other is Jack Denten, two murtherous villains that are resolute.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I prithee call them in that I may see them, and speak with them.

sp.speaker: Forest.
sp.l: Ho Will and Jack.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Here sir, we are at hand.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: These be they that I told you of.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Come hither sirs, to make a long discourse were but a folly, you seem to be resolute in this cause that Myles Forest hath delivered to you, therefore you must cast away pity, and not so much as think upon favour, for the more stern that you are, the more shall you please the King.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: 'swounds sir, never talk to us of favour, it is not the first that Jack and I have gone about.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Well said, but the Kings pleasure is this, that he will have no blood shed in the deed doing, therefore let me hear your advises?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Why then I think this master Terrell that as they sit at supper there should be two dags ready charged, and so suddenly to shoot them both through.

sp.speaker: Terrell.
sp.p: no, I like not that so well, what sayst thou will, what is thy opinion?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Tush, here is more ado than needs, I pray bring me where they are, and I will take them by the heels and beat their brains against the walls.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Nay that I like not, for it is too tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Dout.
sp.p: Then hear me master Terrell, let will take one, and I will take another, and by the life of Jack Douton we will cut both their throats.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Nay sirs, then hear me, I will have it it done in this order, when they be both a bed and at rest, Myles Forest thou shalt bring them up both, and between two feather beds smother them both.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Why this is very good, but stand aside, for here comes the Princes, I will bring you word when the deed is done.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: How fares my noble Lord and loving brother?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: A worthy brother, Richard Duke of Yorke my cause of sorrow is not for myself, but this is it that adds my sorrow more, to see our uncle whom our father left as our Protector in minority, should so digress from duty, love and zeal, so unkindly thus to keep us up prisoners, and know no sufficient cause for it.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: Why brother comfort yourself, for though he detain us a while, he will not keep us long, but at last he will send us to our loving mother again: whither if it please God to send us, I doubt not but our mother would keep us so safe, that all the Prelates in the world should not deprive her of us again: so much I assure myself of. But here comes Myles Forest, I prithee Myles tell my kingly brother some merry story to pass away the time, for thou seest he is melancholy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: no Myles, tell me no merry story, but answer me to one question, what was he that walked with thee in the Garden, methought he had the keys?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: My Lord, it was one that was appointed by the King to be an aid to sir Thomas Brokenbury.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did the King, why Myles Forest, am not I King?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I would have said my Lord your uncle the Protector.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay my kingly uncle I know he is now, but let him enjoy both Crown and kingdom, so my brother and I may but enjoy our lives and liberty. But tell me, is sir Robert Brokenbery clean discharged?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: no my Lord, he hath but charge for a night or two.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay then, new officers, new laws, would we had kept the old still. But who are they whose ghastly looks doth present a dying fear to my living body. I prithee tell me Myles what are they?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: One my Lord is called Jack Denten, the other is called will Slaughter. But why starts your grace?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Slaughter, I pray God he come not to slaughter my brother and me, for from murther and slaughter, good Lord deliver us. But tell me Myles is our lodging prepared?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, if it please your brother and you to walk up.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then come brother, we will go to bed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I will attend upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Come Myles Forest bear us company.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sirs stay you two here, and when they are asleep I will call you up.

sp.speaker: Dent.
sp.p: I promise thee will, it grieves me to see what moan these young Princes make, I had rather than forty pounds I had never taken it in hand, it is a dangerous matter to kill innocent princes, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Why you base slave, are you faint hearted, a little thing would make me strike thee, I promise thee.

sp.speaker: Dent.
sp.l: Nay go forward, for now I am resolute: but come, let us to it.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: I prithee stay, he will call us up anon. But sirrah Jack, didst thou mark how the King started when he heard my name? What will he do when he feels me?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: But ho sirs, come softly, for now they are at rest.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: Come we are ready, by the mass they are asleep indeed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I hear they sleep, and sleep sweet Princes, never wake
no more, for you have seen the last light in this world.

sp.speaker: Luk.
sp.p: Come press them down, it boots not to cry again, Jack upon them so lustily. But master Forest now they are dead What shall we do with them?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Why go and bury them at the heap of stones at the stair foot, while I go and tell master Terrell that the deed is done.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: Well we will, farewell master Forest.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: How now Myles Forest, is this deed dispatched?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Aye sir, a bloody deed we have performed.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: But tell me, what hast thou done with them?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I have conveyed them to the stairs foot among a heap of stones, and anon I will carry them where they shall be no more found again, nor all the chronicles shall never make mention what shall become of them: yet good master Terrell, tell the King my name, that he may but reward me with a kingly thanks.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I will go certify the King with speed, that Myles Forest, will Slaughter, and Jack Denten, they three have done the deed. And so farewell.

body.stage: Enter the Duke of Buckingham with his dagger drawn.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Ah good my Lord, save my life.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Ah villain, how canst thou ask for mercy, when thou hast so unjustly betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: I desire your grace but give me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Aye speak thy last villain, that those that hear it, may see how unjustly thou hast betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Then thus my Lord. First, the proclamation was death to him that harboured your grace.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Ah villain, and a thousand crowns to him that could
betray me.

sp.speaker: Ban.
sp.l: Ah my Lord, my obeisance to my Prince is more.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Ah villain, thou betrayedst me for lucre, and not for duty to thy Prince, why Banister, a good servant thinks his life well spent, that spends it in the quarrel of his master. But villain make thyself ready, and here receive thy death.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: Henry Duke of Buckingham, I arrest thee in King Richards name as a traitor.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: Well Herald, I will obey thy rest. But am I arrested in King Richardes name, usurping Richard, that insatiate blood succour, that traitor to God and man Ah Richard, did I in Guild Hall plead the Orator for thee, and held thee in all thy sly and wicked practises, and for my reward dost thou allot me death? Ah Buckingham, thou playedest thy part and made him King, and put the lawful heirs besides: why then is Buckingham guilty now of his death? yet had not the Bishop of Ely fled, I had escaped.

body.stage: Enters six others,to rescue the Duke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come, the Duke of Buckingham shall not die:
we will take him away by force.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: Why villains, will you be Traitors to your Prince?

sp.speaker: Buckingham.
sp.p: Nay good my friends give me leave to speak, and let me entreat you to lay your weapons by. Then know this country men, the cause I am arrested this, Is for bringing in your lawful King, which is Henry Earl of Richmond now in Britain and means ere long to land at Milford Haven in Wales, where I do know he shall have aid of the chiefest of the Welsh, he is your lawful King, and this a wrongful usurper. When you shall hear of him landed in that place, then take up weapons and amain to him, he is the man must reave you of this yoke, and send the usurper headless to his home, and poor Buckingham prays upon his knees, to bless good Richmond in his enterprise, and when the conquest shall be given to him, grant he may match with Lady Elizabeth, as promise hath to fore by him been past, while then my friends, leave me alone to death, and let me take this punishment in peace. Ah Buckingham, was not thy meaning good in displacing the usurper, to raise a lawful king? Ah Buckingham, it was too late, the lawful heirs were smothered in the Tower, sweet Edward and thy brother, I never slept quiet thinking of your deaths. But vaunt Buckingham, thou wast altogether innocent of their deaths. But thou villain, whom of a child I nursed thee up, and hast so unjustly betrayed thy Lord? Let the curse of Buckingham never depart from thee. Let vengeance, mischiefs, tortures, light on thee and thine. And after death thou mayst more torture feel, than when Exeon turns the restless wheel. And ban thy soul where ere thou seem to rest. But come my my friends, let me away.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: My Lord we are sorry. But come lay hands on Banister.

body.stage: Enter King Richard sir William Catesbie and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The goal is got, and golden Crown is won,
And well deservest thou to wear the same,
that ventured hast thy body and thy soul,
But what boots Richard, now the Diadem
Or kingdom got, by murther of his friends,
My fearful shadow that still follows me,
Hath summoned me before the severe judge,
My conscience witness of the blood I spilt,
Accuseth me as guilty of the fact,
The fact, a damned judgment craves,
Whereas impartial justice hath condemned.
Methinks the Crown which I before did wear,
Enchased with Pearl and costly Diamonds,
Is turned now into a fatal wreathe,
Of fiery flames, and ever burning stars,
And raging fiends hath past their ugly shapes,
in studient lakes, addressed to tend on me,
If it be thus, what wilt thou do in this extremity?
Nay what canst thou do to purge thee of thy guilt?
even repent, crave mercy for thy damned fact,
Appeal for mercy to thy righteous God,
ha repent, not I, crave mercy they that list.
My God, is none of mine. Then Richard be thus resolved,
to pace thy soul in valence with their blood,
Soul for soul, and body for body, yea marry Richard,
that is good, Catesbie.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You called my Lord, I think?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It may be so. But what thinkst thou Catesbie?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Of what my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why of all these troubles.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Why my Lord, I hope to see them happily overcomed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How villain, dost thou hope to see me happily overcomed?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: who you my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye villain, thou points at me, thou hopest to see me overcomed.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: no my good Lord, your enemies or else not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: ha, ha, good Catesbie, but what hearest thou of the Duke of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Why he is dead my Lord, he was executed at Salisbury yesterday.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why it is impossible, his friends hopes that he shall out live me, to be my head.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Out live you, Lord that is strange.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: no Catesbie, if a do, it must be in fames,
And since they hope he shall out live me, to be my head,
He hops without his head, and rests among his fellow rebels.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Marry no force my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But Catesbie, what hearest thou of Henry Earl of Richmond

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Not a word my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: no: hearest thou not he lives in Britain
in favour with the Duke.
Nay more Lady Margaret his mother conspires against us ,
And persuades him that he is lineally descended from Henry
The fourth, and that he hath right to the Crown,
Therefore tell me what thinkst thou of the Earl?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: My Lord, I think of the Earl as he doth deserve,
A most famous gentleman.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villain dost thou praise my foe, and commend him to my face?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Nay my Lord, I wish he were as good a friend as he is a foe, else the due deserts of a traitor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: what is that?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Why my Lord, to loose his head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yea marry, I would it were off quickly, then
But more to the strengthening of his title,
She goes about to marry him to the Queens eldest daughter,
Lady Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord that I heard was concluded,
by all the nobility of Britain

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why then there it goes,
The great devil of hell go with all.
A marriage begun in mischief, shall end in blood:
I think that accursed sorceress the mother Queen,
Doth nothing but be with me, and hatcheth conspiracies,
And brings out perilous birds to wound
Their Countries weal,
The Earl is up in Arms,
And with him many of the Nobility,
He hath aid in France
He is rescued in Britain
